gatt success will take pressure minister long term pressure by trade ministers is necessary if the current uruguay round of talks on the general agreement on trade and tariffs gatt is to succeed new zealand overseas trade minister mike moore said moore told the opening meeting of trade ministers from 22 nations gathered for informal talks on the gatt that ministers need opportunities to keep in touch and to consider how the political problems inherent in an exercise like this one can be faced and resolved moore said the taupo meeting is one of series of such international gatherings which includes the oecd ministerial meeting in may and the meeting in venice in june enabling ministers to maintain contact world trade conditions are getting better not worse he said he said new zealand is moving rapidly and of our own initiative in the direction of liberalisation and warn you we shall be looking for partners

argentina brazil trade jumped 90 pct in 1986 trade between argentina and brazil jumped 90 pct in 1986 versus 1985 foreign minister dante caputo said speaking to reporters caputo said the near doubling in trade showed the tangible and immediate results of wide ranging economic integration accord signed by the presidents of both countries last july he said trade last year totalled billion dlrs versus 700 mln dlrs in 1985 the accord provided for capital goods trade between the two countries to rise to billion dlrs over four years argentine wheat exports to brazil will increase from 375 000 tonnes in 1987 to mln tonnes in 1991 the accord said

february jobs gains show stronger economy momentum in th economy may be picking up given solid across the board increases in the february employment report economists said non farm payroll employment rose 337 000 in february twice what the financial markets expected this follows 319 000 gain in january revised down from previously reported 448 000 increase even if you look at january and february together this is still much stronger report than the consensus expectation in the market said allan leslie of discount corporation economists stressed that gains in hours worked signal much larger gains in february production and income than previously forecast the average work week rose hours to 35 hours from 34 hours in january the average manufacturing work week rose hours to 41 hours the longest factory work week since november 1966 the commerce department said the gains in manufacturing employment point to very large increase in industrial production of between and pct said joe carson of chemical bank this compares to pct gain in january industrial production peter greenbaum of smith barney harris upham and co inc noted that the average wage rate increased to 87 dlrs an hour in february from 83 dlrs in january combined with the increase in hours worked this means we ll get pretty healthy gain in personal income vis vis the wage and salary disbursement he said greenbaum said that february personal income should rise at least pct after being flat in january he said the february employment gains are consistent with his firm first quarter real gross national product growth forecast of pct economists agreed that the employment data were negative for the credit markets in that they signal healthier economy and no easing in the federal reserve monetary policy but most said that the market need not fear tighter policy either this report is another reason for the fed to not consider easing said ray stone of merrill lynch capital markets inc it gives them more room to address the dollar situation he said if they had to nudge policy tighter they could do so but it most likely they ll sit and wait the data have not been uniform stone added durable goods were weak in january and now employment is strong in january durable goods orders dropped pct followed by pct drop in factory goods orders retail sales fell pct and the merchandise trade gap widened to 14 billion dlrs things just aren adding up said steve slifer of lehman goverment securities inc consumer spending capital spending goverment spending and net exports data show very weak first quarter gnp growth of one pct he said the employment and production data point to big inventory build up but that what we thought in the fourth quarter and we only got pct gnp growth manufacturing employment gained 50 000 after falling 15 000 in january economists estimated that 30 000 of the gain was accounted for by striking workers in the steel and machinery industries returning to work even so some economists said that the manufacturing gains have resulted from an improving trade outlook jason benderly of goldman sachs and co noted that the trade picture improved in the fourth quarter as net exports grew at 20 pct annual rate while the rate of increase in imports fell to only six pct and that it continues to improve in the first quarter not only the official statistics for the fourth quarter but evidence of pick up in orders from overseas for paper products chemicals high tech goods and capital goods show that trade is improving benderley said the economy is moving between extremes he said some reports are going to look bad and some good but first quarter gnp is going to grow in the middle at about three pct 287 000 gain in services employment comprised the greater part of february employment gain retail services employment rose 129 000 in february compared to gain of 117 000 in january previously reported at 166 000 construction employment rose slim 000 in february but this follows robust 113 000 gain in january revised down from previously reported 142 000 gain the civilian unemployment rate was unchanged in february at pct this means the jobless rate has stayed at pct for three consecutive months the lowest reading since march 1980 the commerce department noted the federal reserve has to be pleased with this report carson said this takes away the fed flexibility to ease but there no reason to tighten it way too early for that

house panel votes to ease export controls key house panel voted to greatly ease government controls on exports as several house committees moved rapidly toward approval of major changes in trade laws they hope will help solve trade woes the house foreign affairs subcommittee on international economic policy voted to direct the administration to cut the list of controlled exports by 40 per cent by removing items no longer considered important to military security industries had complained they were losing sales to foreign competitors who were allowed to export freely products companies could not sell abroad the issue has been the subject of administration debate the commerce department had held that unnecessary restrictions impeded exports while the defense department said current controls should be retained but better administered four congressional panels met today to consider portions of wideranging trade bill that intends to help companies sell more products abroad and to fight unfair foreign trade practices their separate proposals some of them conflicting will be woven by house democratic leaders into final trade bill for vote by the full house in late april sparked by the proposal of fujitsu ltd to take controlling interest in schlumberger ltd fairchild semiconductor corp the house energy and commerce subcommittee on commerce voted to expand reagan authority to block foreign takeovers of companies reagan would be able to block any takeover found to be damaging to economic or national security interests we are losing our semiconductors which are at the heart of our national security subcommittee chairman james florio new jersey democrat said the subcommittee also called for the administration to consider retaliation against japan for its restrictive government procurement practices the retaliation could be triggered by requirement that the administration investigate whether companies were treated unfairly and whether they have been barred from bids on lucrative public works projects such as the eight billion dlr kansai airport construction firms have complained they were not allowed to bid on its construction at the urging of the recording industry the subcommittee agreed to bar imports of new japanese product digital audio recorders meeting in closed session the house ways and means committee agreed to allow president reagan to retaliate against foreign countries that refuse to open their markets to telecommunications products congressional aides said the committee also agreed companies would be allowed to press for relief from imports of counterfeit products made in violation of copyright and patent laws

senate wants japan semiconducter pact enforced the senate has unanimously called for president reagan immediately to force japan to live up to pledge to stop dumping its microchips and open its markets to chipmakers the senate voted 93 to to urge reagan to impose penalties on japanese high technology products containing semiconductors in retaliation for what it sees as japan violations of the semiconductor pact while the measure does not bind reagan to any action senate leaders said its adoption would warn japan stiffer legislation would be considered if the violations continue we want to send message to japan to let it know how the senate feels about this matter senate democratic leader robert byrd told the senate senate finance committee chairman lloyd bentsen told the senate the measure was not aimed at retaliation but at correcting japan unfair trade practices key house trade lawmaker representative richard gephardt also announced he would seek to force japan and other countries with huge trade surpluses to slash their surplus by 10 pct year for three years

brazil wants to increase steel exports to brazil wants to increase its steel exports to the united states now limited because of tough import restraints set in 1984 by the reagan administration spokeswoman for the brazilian steel institute ibs said brazilian and trade officials held the first of three day meeting today in brasilia to discuss the issue in 1984 after three months of painstaking negotiations the government reached accords with seven steel exporting nations australia brazil japan mexico spain south africa and south korea to reduce their shipments to the united states by about 30 pct in 1985 the 1984 restraints established that for 1987 brazil steel exports to the could not exceed 632 000 tonnes increasing to 640 000 tonnes in 1988 and 670 000 tonnes in 1989 the last of the five year deadline set by the agreements brazilian officials are trying to increase brazil export share of non flat products to the market the spokeswoman said there were reports of domestic supply problems in the united states

may drop tariffs if japan opens yeutter the is willing to drop tariffs on japanese electronic imports if japan shows it will abide by an agreemement opening its markets to american goods trade representative clayton yeutter said in tv interview but there has to be clear indication that they are willing to act he said yeutter said difficulties in the japanese economy caused by the tariffs and the yen rise against the dollar are problems they have brought on themselves the dollar fell to 40 year lows against the yen today certainly the movement of the yen is causing some economic turmoil in japan he said my only response is that we have gone through about five years with the dollar going in just the opposite direction although can sympathise it occurred for only few weeks or months in japan the tarriffs announced on friday by president reagan will affect about 300 million dlrs worth of products only tiny fraction of japan total exports to the even so reagan decision doesn give us any joy we don want to take retaliatory action here if we don have to yeutter said yeutter said the meetings scheduled next month in washington between reagan and prime minister yasuhiro nakasone will include some difficult items on the agenda japan has failed to implement two parts of three part semiconductor agreement yeutter said japan has stopped dumping chips in the but it has failed to open its domestic markets to made chips and has failed to end predatory pricing in third world countries undercutting products he said

baldrige concerned about korean taiwan deficits secretary of commerce malcolm baldrige expressed concern about the continuing trade deficits with south korea and taiwan and said that without an adjustment in exchange rates there is little likelihood of improvement speaking to the president export council an industry advisory group baldrige said the trade deficit issue was under discussion with those countries feel that unless we see an exchange rate adjustment we probably won be able to see much of change in the large surplus that taiwan in particular has with us he said in wide ranging discussion on trade matters baldrige also repeated concern about an attempted takeover by japan fujitsu company of fairchild computer he said that the japanese were resisting allowing companies into the giant computer business while at the same time attempting to acquire control of company that does major computer business in the market lastly baldrige said that the united states was hopeful that it could complete free market agreement with canada by the autumn but said major issues including acid rain remained unresolved

poehl warns against further dollar fall bundesbank president karl otto poehl said weaker dollar would be risky and further appreciation of the mark would damage prospects for sustained west german economic growth in speech to the institute of contempory german affairs here poehl said it would be an extremely risky policy to aim for further substantial decline in the value of the dollar to correct the trade deficit he said the united states could face vicious circle of depreciation inflation and more depreciation if it took that route poehl noted west germany had already taken steps to meet demands for greater stimulation of its domestic economy accelerating tax cuts cutting interest rates and tolerating above target money supply growth he said he would have been happy to have brought forward five billion marks of tax cuts now planned for january 1988 to the beginning of this year but he said the government faced political constraints getting such measures through the upper house of the west german parliament but there were also limits to the impact west germany could accept on exports from rising mark he said poehl said west germany relied on exports for about one third of its gross national product so substantial erosion of export markets could not be offset by increasing demand at home further appreciation of the mark could even be an obstacle to further growth he said poehl said the bundesbank had tolerated rapid money supply growth last year because the country enjoyed low inflation and because external factors including low oil prices and favourable terms of trade had given some extra leeway but poehl said west germany now faced difficult dilemma over monetary policy the underlying rate of inflation was now two pct not the reported negative inflation rates last year and west germany was affected more than before by exchange rate developments for the time being we will have to focus our policy more on the external side and we can live with more expansionary money supply but we must be very careful he said he said he shared some of the concern about japan trade surpluses which affected european countries as well as the united states poehl welcomed the so called louvre accord of monetary officials of major industrialized countries saying the importance of the february 22 agreement to stabilize exchange rates had been underestimated all partners had agreed that the dollar was at about the right level and that further changes would damage growth he said this was remarkable change in attitude especially on the part of our american colleagues he said but he said there was still danger that the correction of the dollar value could overshoot

swedish trade surplus rises in february sweden trade surplus rose to billion crowns in february from billion in january and 48 billion in february 1986 the central bureau of statistics said the trade surplus for the first two months of the year rose to billion crowns from billion in the corresponding period of 1986 the report said february imports stood at 20 billion crowns while exports were 23 billion

paper says trade deficit cut to 13 65 billion the washington post said the commerce department yesterday issued new report showing that the merchandise trade deficit was 13 65 billion dollars in february reduction of billion dlrs from the 15 06 billion figure the department reported only two days earlier the newspaper said news of the unexpectedly large 15 billion deficit helped batter the dollar value on foreign exchange markets and boosted interest rates however the new report went largely unnoticed by financial markets since such downward revision in the deficit is monthly occurrence the washington post said by law the department must first publish what top commerce official agreed are misleading trade figures and then wait 48 hours before putting out the more accurate ones no one was immediately available at the commerce department for comment on the washington post report

australian minister says agriculture gatt priority australian trade minister john dawkins said if the general agreement on tariffs and trade gatt does not give high priority to agricultural trade reform it will be neglecting the area of greatest crisis in statement to the informal gatt trade ministers conference here he said agriculture is problem which involves all countries and seriously affects the debt servicing abilities of number of developing countries he said major countries should be showing leadership on this problem we will be giving close attention to the processes in the oecd organisation of economic cooperation and development and elsewhere leading to the venice economic summit where we will be looking to the participants to adopt strong commitment to agricultural trade reform dawkins said the venice summit is scheduled for june he said australia interests in the uruguay round the eighth under the gatt are wide ranging dawkins said he sees the round as providing timely opportunity to secure further meaningful trade liberalisation in all sectors and to restore confidence in the multilateral system dawkins said initial meetings of the negotiating groups established in geneva after the gatt declaration last september in punta del este uruguay have made reasonable start but it is vital that trade ministers maintain the pressure on these processes we must see that the commitments made at punta del este on standstill and rollback are carried into practice the standstill and rollback of protection offers the global trading system chance to hold and wind back protection during the negotiations which are expected to last up to four years he said

baldrige says japan must open its markets commerce secretary malcolm baldrige said the united states will not stand idly by and let japan dominate the world electronics market baldrige told the senate finance committee the united states would insist japan open its markets to products as the market is open to japanese products asked after his testimony if this meant the united states would close its markets to japan if they did not open theirs baldrige said not prepared to say that but it certainly would be one of the alternatives studied baldrige said in his testimony japan had closed supercomputer market and restricted telecommunications market can only conclude that the common objective of the japanese government and industry is to dominate the world electronics market given the importance of this market to industry in general and our defense base in particular we cannot stand by idly he said he said it was these concerns about national security which led him to express reservations over the proposed acquisition of fairchild semiconductor by fujitsu of japan

european community to set up office in peking china and the european community ec signed an agreement on the establishment of an ec office here chinese vice foreign minister zhou nan and the ec external relations commissioner willy de clercq signed the accord ec sources said the office was likely to open in the second half of this year in 1986 the ec was china third largest trading partner with chinese imports from the ec worth billion dlrs and exports worth billion dlrs de clercq told the official china daily that more joint ventures should be set up in china as way of reducing china trade deficit with the ec the ec affairs in china are currently looked after by whichever country holds the group six monthly rotating presidency now held by the belgians until the danes take over in july

stock market overreacts to tariffs yeutter trade representative clayton yeutter said the stock market overreacted to decision last week to proceed with tariffs on some japanese computer products speaking to reporters prior to testifying at house agriculture committee hearing yeutter said it is difficult to comprehend that trade decision affecting only 300 mln dlrs in goods caused the stock market collapse yesterday have hunch lot of other things were involved in that stock market fall including simple profit taking yeutter said yeutter said japan would be sending senior official from its trade ministry to washington next week for talks on the computer chip dispute we will be glad to have him here but that not going to affect decision that already been made yeutter said the decision announced last week would apply higher tariffs on range of japanese products in retaliation for the alleged failure of tokyo to honor an agreement with the on semiconductor trade

takes tough stand on gatt farm issues the united states is prepared to pull out all the stops to defend its agricultural trade rights under the general agreement on tariffs and trade gatt ambassador to gatt michael samuels said those rights are now being challenged by the european community ec agricultural support policies he told conference sponsored by the american soybean association he reiterated washington firm intention to retaliate if the ec goes ahead and bans imports of hormone fed beef without the issue being investigated by gatt special committee the claims the ec directive due to come into effect on january threatens to cut 100 mln dlrs worth of meat shipments into the ec the also will oppose all ec efforts to impair trade via the ec oilseeds regime which supports ec oilseed prices over the current market level and which may be extended to include hotly disputed oils and fats tax samuels said reduction of trade distorting world agricultural subsidies an aim of most key participants in gatt multilateral trade negotiations is meaningless if import barriers continue to be erected samuels said samuels called the plan to eliminate world farm subsidies by the year 2000 proposed at gatt in july visionary and very serious the ec and japan have said it is unrealistic the ec commission this month announced its draft proposal on farm trade reform expected to be tabled at gatt formally next week the ec scheme involves emergency measures to reduce tensions in troubled surplus sectors of cereals and cereals substitutes dairy and sugar it also calls for reduction of farm subsidies the is not opposed to short term measures as long as they are directly linked to long term commitments to end major trade distortions samuels said washington will review the ec proposal when it is formally submitted and respond to it officially then we will consider its relation to the punta del este declaration to correct trade problems and expand market access the ambassador said the can say no to the ec proposal if the ec ignores the plan when it tables its own proposal he added the key difference between the two approaches is that the wants farm subsidies eliminated while the ec is pushing only for reduction in farm suppports samuels said if the ec farm budget were protected by subsidy freeze there would be little incentive for the community to work to correct the international trade situation he added samuels cited the animal hormones complaint the ec oilseeds regime and an ec regulation concerning meat imports to third countries as three crucial barriers to trade which the wants to see resolved under the auspices of gatt

yeutter seeks stronger taiwan korea currencies trade representative clayton yeutter said he hoped the dollar would continue to decline in relation to the currencies of taiwan and south korea as way to improve the trade picture testifying before the house appropriations subcommittee which must approve his agency 1988 budget he said in my judgment economic factors justify continued decline asked by committee member if he expected further decline and how much yeutter said the taiwan and south korean currencies should be adjusted to reflect positive factors in their economies

senators propose ban on toshiba imports three senators said they will propose temporary ban on imports of all toshiba products due to the company illegal sales of sensitive high technology goods to the soviet union senator jake garn john heinz and richard selby said at hearing of the senate banking committee on export control they will offer the proposal as part of major trade bill when it is brought before the senate this summer garn utah republican said am talking about specific retribution on company that endangers the security of their own country and ours

nakasone to visit washington in late april prime minister yasuhiro nakasone will make an official week long visit to the united states from april 29 and hold talks in washington with president reagan chief cabinet secretary masaharu gotoda told reporters government sources said nakasone would try to resolve growing bilateral trade friction and discuss the june venice summit of western industrial democracies foreign minister tadashi kuranari will accompany nakasone ministry officials said industry sources in washington said the white house economic policy council was recommending trade sanctions against japan for violating the two countries agreement on semiconductor trade under the pact japan pledged to stop dumping microchips in the and asia and open its domestic market to semiconductors

japan march interim trade surplus falls japan customs cleared trade surplus fell to 89 billion dlrs in the first 10 days of march from 91 billion surplus year earlier the ministry of finance said the march interim surplus compared with 70 billion dlr surplus in the same february period fob exports in the first 10 days of march rose pct from year earlier to 50 billion dlrs and cif imports rose pct to 61 billion the average yen dollar rate used for the statistics was 153 67 yen against 181 23 year earlier

gatt meeting hears plea for african debt relief debt among african countries will continue to grow and their economies remain stifled unless developed countries lower their interest rates nigerian trade minister samaila mamman said he told an informal general agreement on tariffs and trade gatt meeting the widening gap between developed and developing countries and an inequitable international economic system were major impediments to growth in developing countries delegates from 23 countries are attending the gatt talks in the new zealand resort of taupo wish to emphasise that the growth in the volume of the external indebtedness of african countries reflects the full effect of the deflationary monetary and trade policies of the developed market economy countries mamman said the developed market economy countries have slowed down output growth thereby drying up markets for the commodity exports of african countries mamman said the world bank estimated 35 billion dlrs year would be needed over the next five years for the african continent to be able to achieve gross domestic product growth gdp rate of three to four pct by 1990 yet at the same time africa debt service was estimated at 24 billion dlrs year between 1986 and 1990 with the best of intentions africa cannot attain three to four pct gdp growth rate if the current high level of debt persists mamman said developed countries must seek alternatives to policies that resulted in the transfer of resources and more indebtedness he said the international community cannot fail to respond positively to the collapse of the international market for commodities and act quickly to stabilize demand and prices of our commodity exports he added

urges surplus nations to boost growth leading industrial nations will be reviewing the paris agreement to stabilize exchange rates foster increased worldwide growth and reduce trade imbalances but the thinks the accord has been successful so far senior treasury official said the paris accord will be reviewed at this meeting it has been successful and continues to be succesfull senior treasury official told reporters in briefing ahead of this week semiannual imf and world bank meetings he also said the was looking to west germany and japan to bolster their economic growth the official said both surplus countries like west germany and japan and deficit countries like the agreed to play role in bringing about more balanced economic growth he reaffirmed the would press ahead with efforts to reduce its budget deficit resist protectionism and boost competitiveness the official also said that he expected trade issues like the dispute between the and japan over microchips to be included in the discussions the official made no direct comment on the content or schedule of forthcoming group of five and group of seven discussions he said that industrial countries are concerned that the large external imbalances remain threat to the international monetary system he added that the meetings will also provide an opportunity to discuss economic policy coordination efforts the official said indicators would be used to measure policy objectives of industrial countries and their economic projections they would also be used to assess progress of policy goals asked whether the was proposing new initiative regarding the indicators the official said the issue would be reported to the venice summit in june monetary sources said the proposal envisages using the indicators to make policy coordination agreements like the paris accord more binding

trade deficit 38 37 billion dlrs in 4th qtr the merchandise trade deficit on balance of payments basis was record 38 37 billion dlrs in the october to december fourth quarter the commerce department said the record trade shortfall came after revised 37 15 billion dlr third quarter deficit the department previously reported the third quarter deficit was 37 67 billion dlrs for the full year 1986 the merchandise trade deficit was record 147 billion dlrs up from 124 billion dlrs in 1985 the department said during the final quarter last year imports rose 78 billion dlrs or three pct to 95 billion dlrs while exports rose 56 billion dlrs or three pct to 57 33 billion dlrs the trade report on balance of payments basis excludes such factors as military sales and the costs of shipping and insurance the commerce department said non petroleum imports in the quarter were up billion dlrs or three pct to 87 billion dlrs with the largest increases in consumer goods which rose billion dlrs and in non monetary gold and passenger cars from canada up 900 mln dlrs each lumber imports from canada fell 300 mln dlrs or 33 pct because of 15 pct duty on imports from canada the department said passenger car imports fell 600 mln dlrs because of an 18 pct decrease in the number of south korean made imported cars and nine pct decrease from japan on the exports side agricultural exports rose 600 mln dlrs or nine pct to billion dlrs primarily because of 104 pct or 600 mln dlr increase in soybean exports soybean shipments to western europe rose sharply because supplies from brazil traditional major exporter were limited by drought commerce said the trade deficit with latin america rose 900 mln dlrs to billion dlrs with japan increased 700 mln dlrs to 14 billion dlrs and with western europe rose 200 mln to billion dlrs in the quarter the deficit with newly industrialized far east countries including hong kong south korea singapore and taiwan fell 500 mln dlrs to eight billion dlrs and with canada the deficit decreased 200 mln dlrs to billion dlrs in the quarter in the full year 1986 imports rose 30 billion dlrs or nine pct to 369 billion dlrs exports increased by only billion dlrs or three pct to 221 billion dlrs commerce said petroleum imports during 1986 fell 16 billion dlrs or 33 pct to 33 billion dlrs because of lower prices the average price per barrel decreased to 14 72 dlrs from 26 41 dlrs agricultural exports fell by billion dlrs or nine pct to 26 billion during the year the average price of rice fell 27 pct cotton was down 22 pct corn 18 pct wheat 16 pct and soybeans nine pct the trade deficit with japan for all of 1986 rose 11 billion dlrs to 54 billion dlrs and with western europe increased billion dlrs to 28 billion dlrs

thai trade deficit widens in first quarter thailand trade deficit widened to billion baht in the first quarter of 1987 from billion year ago the business economics department said it said janunary march imports rose to 65 billion baht from 58 billion thailand improved business climate this year resulted in 27 pct increase in imports of raw materials and semi finished products the country oil import bill however fell 23 pct in the first quarter due to lower oil prices the department said first quarter exports expanded to 60 billion baht from 56 billion export growth was smaller than expected due to lower earnings from many key commodities including rice whose earnings declined 18 pct maize 66 pct sugar 45 pct tin 26 pct and canned pineapples seven pct products registering high export growth were jewellery up 64 pct clothing 57 pct and rubber 35 pct

china trade deficit falls in january china trade deficit in january fell to 310 mln dlrs from 460 mln in january 1986 the china daily business weekly said quoting customs figures the paper said exports fell to 75 billion dlrs from 84 billion and imports fell to 06 billion from billion

canada to monitor steel imports exports canada plans to monitor steel shipments flowing in and out of the country in an attempt to appease concerns in the over the high level of canadian steel exports trade minister pat carney said to help maintain our open access to the steel market the government is taking further action to ensure we have more accurate data on exports and imports and that canada is not used as backdoor to the market by offshore suppliers carney said carney also said canadian companies were being asked to exercise prudence in the market and both countries were considering establishing joint commission to study the growing steel problem carney told the house of commons she will soon announce an amendment to the exports and imports permits act to set up the monitoring program canadian steel shipments to the have risen to pct cent of the market in recent months almost double the level just two years ago canadian trade officials said the increase in canadian shipments comes at time of growing anger in the over rising steel imports from several countries in the face of decline in the domestic steel industry some lawmakers have proposed canada share of the american market be limited to pct

german current account surplus widens in february west germany current account surplus widened to provisional billion marks in february from slightly downwards revised billion in january spokeswoman for the federal statistics office said the trade surplus in february widened to provisional 10 billion marks from billion in january she added the statistics office had originally put the january current account surplus at billion marks the february trade surplus was well up on the 84 billion mark surplus posted in the same month of 1986 but the current account surplus was down slightly from the 85 billion surplus recorded in february 1986 statistics office statement said the widening of the february current account surplus compared with january was due to seasonal factors neither the trade nor current account figures are seasonally adjusted february imports measured in terms of value totalled 32 11 billion marks decline of 10 pct against february 1986 but rise of pct against january exports in february also in value terms totalled 42 56 billion marks pct less than in february 1986 but up 13 pct compared with january the statistics office said it was not yet able to calculate the real change in exports and imports in february but for comparison purposes it noted that in january the average value of imports had fallen 15 pct year on year while the average value of exports had declined by only pct within the current account the services account had 300 mln marks deficit supplementary trade items 200 mln mark surplus while transfer payments posted billion mark deficit taking the first two months of 1987 together imports in value terms fell 14 pct to 62 billion marks compared with year earlier the value of exports totalled 80 billion marks decline of pct against the same months of 1986 the resulting trade surplus of 17 billion marks for january february compares with cumulative surplus of 14 billion marks in the year ago period the cumulative current account surplus for january and february 1987 totalled 11 billion marks against 11 billion marks year earlier the statistics office said bank economists said the rise in the february trade surplus reflected an improvement in the terms of trade as well as seasonal factors the federal statistics office said earlier this week that february import prices fell pct against january while export prices were unchanged the rise in the nominal figures masks lower export trend that is not expected to change for several months at least said an economist he said the nominal trade surplus for 1987 as whole is likely to fall only slightly from the record 112 billion marks in 1986 but other economists said the surplus could fall to around 80 billion marks an economist at the bank fuer gemeinwirtschaft bfg in frankfurt said two month comparison of trade figures gave more accurate picture of west germany trade position he noted the 17 billion mark surplus for january and february together was lower than the 21 billion mark surplus posted in november and december the trend is clearly lower he said this economist who declined to be named said the february rise was also partly explained by special factors in january when there had been number of public holidays as well as extremely cold weather both of which hindered trade

african states agree to regional tariff cuts fifteen countries in eastern and southern africa have agreed to cut tariffs on regional trade by 10 pct every two years up to 1996 statement by the preferential trade area pta which seeks to create common market stretching from ethiopia in the north to lesotho in the south said the governments would make the first tariff cut next year in 1996 they would assess the impact of the tariff reductions and work out new timetable for the complete elimination of all barriers to trade by the year 2000 the pta set up in 1982 groups burnudi the comoros djibouti ethiopia kenya lesotho malawi mauritius rwanda somalia swaziland tanzania uganda zambia and zimbabwe pta sources said the agreement averted split between members wanting more progress towards free trade and weaker states concerned about the effects on customs revenue the reductions cover only common list of 300 or so widely traded commodities and goods but pta sources said the organisation planned to expand the list to include 425 items

south korea to maintain trade surplus years south korean trade minister rha woong bae said his nation would maintain trading surplus for three to five years as way to cut its foreign debt he said in trade interests ready for battle in house lawmakers are gearing up for showdown between protectionists and free traders as major trade bill winds its way through committees to vote by the full house of representatives in late april in move to toughen enforcement of trade laws key house subcommittee last week approved toned down version of legislation to require president reagan to retaliate against foreign countries that follow unfair trade practices the bill will be the cornerstone of congressional efforts to restore competitiveness of american industries and turn around last year record 169 billion dlrs trade deficit generally the bill provisions toughen enforcement of trade laws the trade bill forces the administration to act rapidly on complaints of unfair trade practices such as dumping products in the united states at prices below cost of production it also forces the administration to act rapidly when an industry complains that surge in imports threatens its existence in writing the bill the subcommittee rejected calls for trade relief for specific industries such as textiles several lawmakers have argued the new trade bill made too many concessions to reagan and said they intend to back amendments to get tough with countries that violate trade agreements or keep out products but congressmen known for their allegiance to free trade said the bill ties reagan hands too much in trade disputes and they will seek to restore his negotiating powers bill frenzel mi said the subcommittee bill was not one that free trader like me could endorse in all respects but he emphasized there was consensus among lawmakers to work toward bill reagan and republicans would ultimately endorse the goal of trade legislation was to make our trade policy stronger without violating our international trade agreements he said in key concession made at the urging of ways and means committee chairman dan rostenkowski il the trade subcommittee backed off requirement that would have forced reagan to impose automatically quotas or tariffs on imports from countries that engage in unfair trade practices it also agreed the president may waive any retaliation if it would hurt the economy rostenkowski insisted the more moderate approach was necessary if the house wanted to pass bill reagan would sign into law reagan last year blocked senate consideration of tough house trade bill he branded as protectionist and this year he only reluctantly agreed to support trade bill when he saw democratic leaders were determined to pass such legislation white house spokesman marlin fitzwater told reporters late last week that the administration still did not like some of the bill provisions but he added generally we feel very good about the bipartisan consideration of the trade legislation think we are progressing very well the first battle will take place next week when the full house ways and means committee considers an amendment by rep richard gephardt mo to force countries like japan south korea and taiwan to cut their trade surpluses with the the subcommittee limited the gephardt plan to provide only that the existence of large trade surplus with the united states will trigger an investigation of unfair trade practices but would not automatically set off retaliation organized labor has pressed lawmakers for more relief from imports where jobs have been lost to foreign competition afl cio president lane kirkland this year angered the administration when he said any trade bill reagan would sign would not be worth passage in congress but rostenkowski set the tone of the trade debate by saying not trying to write legislation to please lane kirkland trying to write legislation that will be signed by the president rep ed jenkins ga intends to push separately bill to protect the domestic textile and shoe industry an aide said reagan vetoed similar measure last year house speaker jim wright of texas one of the most influential proponents of aid for specific industries beset by low priced foreign competition last week renewed his call for import relief for the domestic oil industry and announced his support for senate plan to trigger temporary oil import tariff when imports reach half of domestic consumption

growth officials and businessmen from around the world said as the dollar today slipped to record low below 145 yen making japanese exporters and holders of dollar investments grit their teeth harder last year the document was prepared by private committee formed by prime minister yasuhiro nakasone and led by former bank of japan head haruo maekawa it recommended that to stop friction due to its large trade surpluses japan must make historical transformation in its traditional policies on economic management and the nation lifestyle there can be no further development for japan without this transformation americans and europeans took the report to heart and have looked in vain for clear signs of this historic change but the japanese remain doubtful about the short or even medium term mln dlrs on japanese exports to the on the grounds japan had abrogated bilateral semiconductor pact british prime minister margaret thatcher threatened to block japanese financial firms from london group keidanren spotted the dangers inherent in such contradictory views last november when he visited the european community related to this matter of trade imbalance the point that found to be of great cause for alarm during this trip to europe was the excessive degree of hope placed by the europeans in the results of the maekawa report he said we explained that the process of restructuring the economy away from its dependence on exports toward balance between domestic and external demand would take time saito said saito words were ignored in february ec industrial policy director heinrich von moltke came to japan and said only know that your government under the leadership of maekawa points to restructuring your economy into less outward looking more inward looking one it is the maekawa report which has attracted the most attention in europe and europeans and americans want quick action far better answer than protectionism would be structural change within the japanese economy the kind suggested by the maekawa report and we hope to see changes occur in the near future visiting chairman of general motors roger smith said in march such expectations are now ingrained which was partly the fault of nakasone who heralded maekawa report as sea of change in japanese affairs said officials months before the report was issued and ec business leaders met their japanese colleagues to discuss the trade problem we are more anxious than ever that the new approach of the maekawa committee does lead to speedy and effective action said ec industrial union leader lord ray pennock the important implication of the maekawa report is that it is finally looking to let japanese enjoy the fruits of their labour said philip caldwell senior managing director of shearson lehman brothers contents of the report were leaded well ahead of issuance japanese officials say they are implementing the report as fast as they can said european ambassador who has travelled the country asking about this issue he said people mentioned many things in line with the spirit of the report including restructuring of the coal and steel industries major misunderstanding is that the private report was government policy europeans are confused about this underlined by von moltke reference to the leadership of the maekawa report even so japanese officials point to last september government
