dealers say nakasone comment too late remarks by japan prime minister yasuhiro nakasone that last month meeting agreed to stabilize the dollar above 150 yen have come too late to influence currency trading dealers said after nakasone statement the dollar rose to 146 40 50 yen from an initial low of 144 20 40 and new york friday finish of 147 15 25 but the rebound was largely on short covering they said think nakasone desperate said bank foreign exchange manager nakasone told lower house budget committee in parliament that japan and other industrialized nations committed themselves in paris last month to stabilize the dollar above 150 yen finance minister kiichi miyazawa told the same committee that the six britain canada france japan the and west germany had intervened aggressively since the dollar fell below 150 yen his nakasone remarks should have been made and should have had bigger influence when the dollar was still above 150 yen said tam of morgan guaranty trust tam said the dollar has hit short term chart targets and is likely to rebound but he warned of another dip to below 145 yen dealers said the worsening trade relations between the and japan will continue to depress the dollar the trade issue has now become political issue since the reagan administration is facing uproar in congress over th3pygks in cutting the country 169 billion dlr trade deficit they said

said unfairly protecting defense industry britain defence minister george younger said the was unfairly protecting its defence industry and this could lead to british firms demanding counter measures younger told chamber of commerce meeting that legislators were failing to realise the true nature of the two way street in terms of ideas technology and equipment british parliamentary report said that up to march british firms had been awarded just 34 mln dlrs worth of contracts for the strategic defence initiative compared with the billion dlrs britain had hoped to secure the committee said technology export restrictions and selectiveness towards foreign contractors had denied british competitors more lucrative orders and largely excluded them from technological research for sdi younger said london had given companies contracts under conditions of fair and open competition all we ask is for our companies to be given similar opportunities he added if new american legislation aimed at curbing unfair subsidies was used to exclude foreign suppliers it would not be surprising if british firms pressed for retaliatory measures younger said

brazil sept trade surplus highest of the year brazil september trade surplus was the best so far this year totalling 494 billion dlrs compared with 434 billion dlrs in august and 540 mln dlrs in september last year banco do brasil foreign trade department cacex director namir salek said in news conference september exports were 694 billion dlrs slightly down from 76 billion dlrs in august imports in september amounted to billion dlrs against 32 billion dlrs in august salek said the accumulated surplus in the jan sept period was 857 billion dlrs compared with 667 billion dlrs in similar 1986 period coffee accounted with 320 mln dlrs of exports up from 222 mln dlrs in august and 212 mln in september 1986 salek said the cacex director said he expected the country trade surplus to average 800 mln dlrs in the remaining three months of the year estimating the year overall surplus to reach 10 billion dlrs from 25 billion dlrs worth of exports and 15 billion dlrs of imports he attributed the good surplus on exports of manufactured and semimanufactured goods he mentioned car exports which accounted alone with sales of 617 mln dlrs in the jan sept period against 194 mln dlrs in similar 1986 period

sprinkel says tax hike would not reduce deficit council of economic advisers chairman beryl sprinkel said the reagan administration remains strongly opposed to tax increase including 18 billion dlrs of new revenues in the budget plan by congressional democrats we believe that significant increases in taxes would not reduce deficits and could have adverse effects on growth sprinkel told the house rules committee he said the administration wanted to continue its policy of gradually reducing deficits through restraining government spending and promoting economic growth sprinkel said cutting the budget deficit was the best way to lower the trade deficit

gatt case against japan model for lyng agriculture secretary richard lyng said the ruling of gatt panel on trade complaint against japan expected soon may influence the stance in negotiations with tokyo on beef and citrus import quotas the ruling of gatt tribunal on demand that japan end quotas on 12 categories of food items is expected by the end of the year lyng said he is optimistic the ruling will favor the these are quota items and the principles that apply to them it seems to me will have some bearing on the question of whether you would have quotas or not on beef and citrus lyng told reuters in an interview he repeated the demand that japan lift the quotas on beef and citrus after march 31 next year the japanese quotas on 12 food categories which the united states has challenged include items such as tomato paste some cheeses and specialty fruit juices officials had hoped ruling against the quotas would be issued earlier this year but the gatt panel decision has been delayed by the illness of the tribunal chairman the has taken hardline stance on the beef and citrus quotas which tokyo says must remain in place to protect japanese farmers we will not negotiate new quotas or accept new quotas on beef and citrus if they impose them we would consider that an illegal action in the gatt lyng said he declined to say what action the would take next april if japan continues to resist demands

japan chip makers angered by sanction plans japanese computer chip makers reacted angrily to news the united states plans to take retaliatory action against them for allegedly failing to live up to an agreement on trade in computer microchips electronic industries association of japan eiaj chairman shoichi saba stated eiaj believes that it is premature and even irrational to attempt an assessment of the impact of the agreement and our efforts to comply with it only six months after concluding the agreement we urge governmental authorities to reconsider the decision made to evaluate fairly the results of japanese efforts in implementing the objectives of the agreement and to resist emotional biases he said yesterday washington announced plans to slap as much as 300 mln dlrs in tariffs on japanese imports in retaliation for what is sees as japan failure to comply with the terms of the pact the agreement struck late last year after months of heated negotiations called on japan to stop selling cut price chips on world markets and to buy more american made semiconductors to salvage the pact tokyo has instructed its chip makers to slash production and has helped establish multi lateral organisation designed to promote chip imports saba said that japanese chip companies have pledged three mln dlrs over the next five years to the new organisation and expressed regret that no american company has seen fit to join this suggests that american semiconductor manufacturers may not be really interested in participating in the japanese market he said

tokyo bids to stop chip row turning into trade war japan is seeking to prevent its computer chips dispute with the from erupting into full scale trade war government officials said we hope that the dispute on this specific issue won have an adverse effect on our overall relationship with the united states ministry of international trade and industry miti official said on friday washington announced plans for as much as 300 mln dlrs in tariffs on japanese electronic goods for tokyo alleged failure to live up to bilateral computer chip pact that agreement reached last year after heated negotiations called on japan to stop selling cut price chips in world markets and to buy more american made semiconductors foreign ministry officials immediately tried to isolate the fall out from the dispute by seeking to separate it from prime minister yasuhiro nakasone planned trip to washington at the end of april while japan has already done about all it can to make sure the chip pact is working the government is studying measures it can take in other fields to defuse american anger and ensure the trip success they said the perception of japan in the congress is very bad one official told reuters we would very much like to do something to respond to that in an apparent effort to prevent the chip dispute from spreading to other areas miti officials sought to depict the action as severe warning to japanese semiconductor makers not to the government faced with belligerent domestic chip industry and an angry american congress the japanese government has been forced to walk an increasingly fine line in the semiconductor dispute trade analysts said they said that it was an open secret that japan largest chip maker nec corp was not happy with what it viewed as the draconian measures miti was taking to implement the pact included enforced production cuts the angry response of japanese chip makers yesterday to the announcement of the tariffs highlighted the difficulties the government faces in taking further action japanese semiconductor manufacturers have complied with the japan agreement said shoichi saba chairman of the electronic industries association of japan he accused the of being irrational he said the action had made the bilateral chip pact meaningless saba comments contrasted with those of prime minister yasuhiro nakasone who said tokyo wanted to solve the dispute through consultations japan is expected to send high level official to washington early next month to try to convince the not to go ahead with the tariffs on april 17 trade analysts say tokyo is likely to outline industry plans to step up purchases of chips and to propose joint investigation into washington allegations of chip dumping

soviet trade deficit with west soars in 1986 the soviet trade deficit with the west almost quadrupled last year reaching 72 billion roubles compared with 713 mln in 1985 official figures showed statistics published by the monthly journal foreign trade showed soviet trade turnover for 1986 fell to 130 billion roubles from 142 billion the previous year drop of pct moscow trade surplus with east bloc countries continued to grow in 1986 western analysts attributed the deficit rise with the west to the world oil price slump which hit moscow main export and cut hard currency earnings needed for purchases in the west

korea says japan complains to gatt on trade plan japan has complained to the secretariat of the general agreement on tariffs and trade gatt that south korea five year plan to cut its trade deficit with japan breaks gatt rules trade ministry officials here said they said japan submitted report earlier this month alleging south korea plan to import less from japan and more from the and elsewhere was tantamount to creating non tariff trade barriers south korea unveiled the plan in november it said it hoped to narrow its trade deficit with japan to two billion dlrs by 1991 south korea trade deficit with japan was record 45 billion dlrs in 1986 and rose to 752 mln dlrs in the first two months of 1987 from 727 mln in the same 1986 period the plan envisages giving incentives to importers not to import japanese goods and to exporters to sell more to japan the officials said they believed the japanese action one step short of filing suit was designed to bring south korea to the negotiating table and stop the plan the seoul government wants tokyo to ease various import restrictions and simplify customs inspections for south korean goods to help reduce the trade deficit

bank of japan calls for long term efforts on trade the short term effect of foreign exchange rate movements in correcting international trade imbalances appears to be waning and long term efforts are required to cut japan chronic dependence on external demand the bank of japan said in monthly report japan trade surplus in nominal terms is likely to remain high in the near future the central bank said fundamental adjustments will be needed as long as japan hopes to benefit from better international allocation of resources and maintain the free trade system it added

lyng pleased ec to offer gatt farm proposal agriculture secretary richard lyng said he is pleased the european community plans to offer global farm reform plan at gatt later this month although the united states opposes key parts of the proposal we re pleased that they have moved in tabling proposal it will help us in getting the negotiations underway lyng told reuters in an interview tuesday lyng comment came after ec ministers in luxembourg endorsed farm reform package drafted by the ec commission the ec plan will be presented at the next meeting of uruguay round agriculture negotiators in geneva on october 26 lyng said the united states would oppose parts of the plan seeking market sharing agreement for grains and proposing curbs on soybean and cereal substitute exports to europe the in july proposed to gatt the elimination of all farm subsidies affecting trade within ten years and has pressed the ec to make counter offer with the aim of reaching global farm subsidy agreement by the end of 1988 however the ec and some domestic groups have said the reagan administration plan to end all farm trade subsidies is unrealistic asked about such criticism lyng said the alternative to doing that is to say that we preserve them and maintain them think that is the unrealistic position would suggest that they ec listen to what we are trying to say lyng also rejected suggestions the and ec agree freeze in export subsidies to get the gatt negotiations started all that some countries would like to have would be wheat agreement where we would stop export subsidies on wheat that doesn do thing for us lyng said the united states wants an end to subsidies in range of agricultural products from dairy products to vegetable oils he said at the gatt negotiators meeting next week canada is expected to offer proposal as well as the ec the united states will be represented at the meeting by former agriculture undersecretary daniel amstutz recently appointed special negotiator on agriculture

new zealand economy forecast to improve in 1987 88 new zealand inflation and interest rates should decline and the balance of payments improve significantly in the fiscal year to the end of march 1988 the institute of economic research nzier said the independent institute said in its quarterly march issue that it was also revising its fiscal 1987 real gross domestic product gdp forecast to fall of pct against the one pct drop forecast in december government figures show gdp grew at an annual pct in the quarter to september and pct in the june quarter the nzier said the sharp improvement in the june and september quarters was due mainly to new tax structure and the introduction of 10 pct value added goods and services tax and is not expected to continue in the second half of 1986 87 the government tight fiscal position is not expected to change it said annual inflation measured by the consumer price index is forecast to fall to nine pct by next march from 18 pct in calendar 1986 it said falling inflation is likely to give significant scope for reductions in nominal interest rates real interest rates are also expected to ease albeit slightly as the balance of payments deficit and hence the call on overseas capital falls away the nzier said short term interest rates are forecast to remain between 20 and 25 pct until the june quarter but will decline over the second half of 1987 88 to between 16 and 18 pct long term rates are expected to fall to between 14 and 16 pct five year government bond rates are currently 18 40 pct and the key indicator 30 day bank bills 26 53 pct the local dollar is expected to depreciate steadily in the early part of the coming year and by next march reach 57 on the reserve bank trade weighted index which is based on basket of currencies the index now stands at around 66 marked improvement in the balance of payments is forecast the nzier said the current account deficit is expected to fall from pct of gdp in 1985 86 to pct in 1986 87 and pct in 1987 88 the current account deficit is forecast to shrink to 32 billion dlrs in 1987 88 from 40 billion in 1986 87 and 33 billion in 1985 86 the 1987 88 budget deficit is forecast to be billion dlrs against an expected billion dlrs in 1986 87 and 87 billion in 1985 86 this compares with the government 1986 87 deficit figure of 92 billion against an earlier forecast of 45 billion conditions in the coming year are sufficiently subdued to contribute to marked improvements in both the balance of payments and the rate of inflation the nzier said overall these are significant gains for the new zealand economy and if they continue to be improved upon bode well for future prospects

nakasone hard pressed to soothe anger on trade prime minister yasuhiro nakasone will visit washington next month in bid to defuse mounting anger over japanese trade policies but western diplomats said they believed his chances of success were slim boxed in by powerful political pressure groups and widespread opposition to his tax reform plans nakasone will be hard pressed to come up with anything new to tell president ronald reagan and key congressmen they said news of the week long visit starting april 29 coincided with news that japan recorded 14 billion dlr trade surplus last month more than 70 pct higher than year earlier it also came one day after the reagan administration economic policy council decided to take retaliatory action against japan for its alleged failure to live up to joint trade agreement on computer microchips nakasone wants to go armed with two separate packages one designed to pep up japan sagging economy and imports in the short term the other to redirect the country in the medium term away from its over dependence on exports for growth but government officials said political infighting could rob both packages of much of their punch and might even prevent one from seeing the light of day nakasone has insisted that the government would not draw up package of short term economic measures until after its 1987 88 budget passed parliament because he feared that would amount to tacit admission that the budget was inadequate but his hopes for quick passage of the budget in time for his trip have been shattered by parliamentary boycott by opposition parties protesting over the sales tax plan faced with the possibility that he might have to go to the virtually empty handed nakasone today ordered his ruling liberal democratic party ldp to come up with its own measures he can then tell reagan the ldp package will form the basis of the government plans without losing face in parliament over the budget political analysts said officials working on the government short term economic package said it would probably include interest rate cuts on loans by government corporations deregulation measures to pass on some of the benefits of the strong yen to consumers in the form of lower prices and accelerated public investment they said record portion of state investment planned for the entire 1987 88 fiscal year will take place in the first half probably over 80 pct diplomats said that was unlikely to be enough to satisfy reagan who is under pressure from the democrat controlled congress to take greater action to cut the huge american trade deficit to complement the short term measures nakasone is also likely to present reagan with details of japan longer term economic plans high ranking advisory body headed by former bank of japan governor haruo maekawa is expected to come up with final report outlining concrete steps to redirect the economy days before nakasone is scheduled to leave for washington its recommendations are designed as follow up to maekawa report last year on economic restructuring and are likely to cover such potentially politically explosive areas as agricultural reform and land policy officials said while wanting to make the report as explicit and detailed as possible they said the political realities might force them to water down some of the committee recommendations subcommittee is considering what the japanese economy might look like in the medium to longer term after it undergoes massive restructuring officials said the subcommittee projects that the current account surplus will fall to less than two pct of japan total output or gross national product around 1993 or 1995 last year the surplus which measures trade in goods and services amounted to over four pct of gnp the subcommittee also projects annual economic growth for japan of nearly four pct over that period and very gradual appreciation of the yen to about 130 to the dollar by around 1993 from 150 now

japan cuts chip supply may produce shortage japan is attempting to cut back semiconductor production to forstall the 300 mln dlrs in tariffs on japanese electronic goods set to take effect april 17 industry analysts said the move is likely to create sharp price rise and possible shortage of the key computer components in the next few weeks the analysts said prices have gone up for memory components the mainstay of the japanese semiconductor industry analyst drew peck of donaldson lufkin and jenrette said but analysts said the price rises have been slight so far and some questioned whether japan would be successful in forcing japanese companies to cut production in the long run others however were more optimistic saying evidence was already in hand that japan has cut back prodution and halted sales to the grey market the third country brokers that sell chips at below production costs we ve seen the grey market begin to dry up for rams and it has virtually dried up for eproms said merrill lynch analyst thomas kurlack of the two key memory chips used in computers prices are inching up and lead times on deliveries are stretching kurlack added industry analysts said japan ministry of international trade and industry or miti had requested the cut backs in production to meet the terms of last year semiconductor accord with the the reagan adminsitration recently proposed tariffs on japanese electronic goods alleging that japan had failed to live up to the accord and continued to dump the computer components in the market but some analysts said japan attempt to mollify the was double edged sword and might be read at subtle form of trade retaliation for the tariffs proposed by the as production in japan is cut these analysts argue prices will rise in the and few american semiconductor manufactures will be able to take up the slack since most long ago exited the market for memory chips computer makers that use the chips in their machines will then be pressured the japanese are looking for ways to reduce trade pressures from washington but at the same time they re demonstating their muscle analyst peck said the cut backs in japanese production are expected to benefit chip makers think this could be very important factor for semiconductor manufacturers industry analyst elliot levine of ladenburg thalmann co said but analyst peck said it will take few weeks to see whether japan has genuinely cut production he said japanese manufactures were likely to view miti request unfavorably because chip capacity was still high and production cut backs would lead to significant write offs in plant and equipment

economic spotlight polish sanctions poland says sanctions have cost its economy 15 billion dlrs and has made clear it wants washington to take lead in repairing the damage after lifting remaining restrictions two weeks ago polish officials are unable to provide precise breakdown of the figure saying it takes into account number of hypothetical losses some of them are too sophisticated to convert into financial terms one banking source said but western economic experts say the effect of sanctions is impossible to calculate they say it is blurred by the poor performance of poland economy and dismiss the 15 billion dlr figure as illusory sanctions have provided very useful excuse for under achieving they did have bad effect yes but they only contributed to largely internal economic problems one said the imposed the measures and withdrew most favoured nation mfn trading status from poland in 1982 in retaliation for suppression of the solidarity free trade union under martial law the estimated cost to the polish economy was originally devised several years ago by the institute of national economy an offshoot of the central planning commission according to one western envoy an expert on polish economic affairs it extrapolated 1979 information on growth trends in trade with the united states as well as increases in credits from western commercial and government lenders but the calculations were based on time when trade was booming and credits still flowed freely he said dismissing the estimate as theoretical projection based on high point which has no real scientific evaluation foreign trade ministry official said polish exports to the in the late 1970s averaged around 400 mln dlrs annually and had fallen by half since the sanctions were imposed imports have suffered slumping from around 800 mln dlrs to 200 mln as credits ran out poland has dwindling trade surplus with the west last year it was one billion dlrs against targeted billion official figures show acknowledging that sanctions have lost poland important markets including agricultural equipment textiles chemicals and some foodstuffs western economists say credits dried up for economic not political reasons poland is accusing the west of letting economic relations deteriorate for political reasons said one expert it an illusion based on misunderstanding of western economy there limit to how much you can go on giving someone who has no hope of repaying it another said adding that poland had benefited from global phenomenon of easy credits in the 1970s which were no longer today reality describing the 15 billion dlr assessment as nebulous one diplomat said it also included losses of hypothetical orders and setbacks to polish research through the curbing of scientific links and exchanges western officials say the lifting of sanctions and new mfn status will have little impact on poland which has hard currency debt of 33 billion dlrs and lacks the means to modernise its industry mfn doesn really mean anything only that poland will not be treated worse than other countries it will be difficult to regain access to the market because different forces are in play now said one western envoy he said polish products were not competitive and their quality was too low trade wars and possible protectionist measures amongst the japan and europe would also hamper poland efforts to regain entry deputy foreign trade minister janusz kaczurba recognised this fact recently kaczurba told the official pap news agency recently making up our lost position will take long time and be uncommonly difficult and in certain cases impossible in period of two to three years it will be possible to increase the level of exports by only about 100 mln dlrs while poland is unlikely to seek compensation it says it has moral right to assistance from the which it says imposed the sanctions illegally but western economist said the argument that sanctions were unilateral torpedoing of the polish economy won cut any ice the americans will just reply that the poles acted immorally in crushing solidarity nevertheless polish national bank head wladyslaw baka in talks in washington last week with the international monetary fund imf and world bank made it clear that poland was looking for lead from the united states he was quoted by pap as saying that poland would meet its financial obligations to the united states but not in short time and not without cooperative stand on the part of its foreign economic partners he stressed that the had particular opportunity to play part in the cooperative policy of poland partners interested in the settlement of polish debt putting it more sharply one senior banking official blamed washington for obstructing talks with the world bank imf and paris club of western creditor governments in recent years and said it should now play more positive role as major superpower the united states can influence international organisations he said citing recent meetings aimed at stabilising currencies as an example of the extent to which western nations were prepared to cooperate

peru has first trade deficit in four years peru registered 16 mln dlr trade deficit in 1986 its first trade shortfall in four years central bank statement said the figure compared with surpluses of 17 billion dlrs in 1985 01 billion in 1984 and 293 mln in 1983 the last trade deficit was 428 mln shortfall in 1982 peru exports fell to 51 billion dlrs last year from 98 billion in 1985 last year imports were 53 billion dlrs against 81 billion dlrs in 1985
volcker sees no clearcut evidence that trade deterioration has yet been reversed

house panel approves trade bill the house ways and means trade subcommittee unanimously approved toned down version of legislation designed to toughen trade laws and wedge open foreign markets to more goods the measure now goes to the full house ways and means committee next week but major changes are not expected congressional sources said this product could very well be toughening our trade policy and doing it in manner that opens markets without this frightening word protectionism ways and means chairman dan rostenkowski an illinois democrat said the trade subcommittee backed away from mandating specific retaliation against foreign countries for unfair foreign trade practices as the house had approved in trade bill last year but it held over for the full ways and means committee debate on controversial plan by rep richard gephardt to mandate reduction in trade surpluses with the by countries such as japan south korea and taiwan gephardt missouri democrat has not decided the exact form of his amendment an aide said last year the house approved his idea to force an annual 10 pct trade surplus cut by those countries

baker denies dollar target exists treasury secretary james baker again said the meeting of six major industrial nations in paris last month did not establish target exchange rate for the dollar baker said in television interview aired here yesterday we don have target for the dollar he declined to comment on what might be desired level for the dollar saying we really don talk about the dollar he said protectionism was becoming extremely strong in the in response to widening trade deficits and import barriers in other countries the mood in the united states is extremely disturbing it extremely strong he said as ve said before we sort of see ourselves as engaged here in real struggle to preserve the world free trading system because if the largest market in the world the goes protectionist we run the risk of moving down the same path that the world did in the late 1930s he said while relative exchange rates had role to play in defusing the threat of protectionism it alone did not offer any solution he said you must address this problem on the exchange rate side but it cannot be solved on the exchange rate side alone it far more comprehensive and broad than that and the solution of it requires comprehensive approach baker said in the interview baker said it would be necessary for other countries to adjust their currencies upwards as well as remove their barriers to imports but he did not elaborate or name any countries

more pressure urged for asia to take beef congressmen from beef producing states and representatives of the livestock industry urged the reagan administration to press japan and south korea to open up their markets to imports of beef testifying at house subcommittee hearing on livestock issues rep hal daub nebr said the administration should push hard for greater beef imports by japan and south korea daub was joined by several other lawmakers assistant trade representative suzanne earley replied we re not going to let japan off the hook or korea she noted trade representative clayton yeutter met with senior korean official last week on the beef issue and that yeutter and agriculture secretary richard lyng will visit tokyo in april for discussions on farm trade issues japan maintains quota on beef imports set at 58 400 tonnes high quality beef in fiscal 1987 south korea has banned beef imports but there are indications seoul may bow to pressure and allow some imports soon industry officials said in testimony today tom cook director of industry affairs for the national cattlemens association said the congress administration and the industry must take strong tough and united stand to impress the japanese that we mean business and that we expect them to open their markets

france reduces trade deficit in february france posted seasonally adjusted trade deficit of 400 mln francs in february after billion franc deficit in january the finance ministry said for the first two months of this year the trade deficit on seasonally adjusted basis was billion francs unadjusted the february deficit was billion francs and the two month cumulative deficit billion the ministry said in statement the ministry said february exports totalled 73 billion francs an pct increase on january while imports totalled 74 billion francs an increase of pct farm and food trade showed two billion franc surplus after surplus of billion in january the energy deficit was reduced to billion francs from eight billion in january while industrial trade showed surplus of billion francs against only 800 mln francs in january

trade surplus 119 mln dlrs in february preliminary trade figures for february show an excess of exports over imports of 119 mln dlrs statistics department statement said this compares with mln dlr deficit revised from mln in january and 36 mln dlr deficit in february 1986 exports rose to 998 mln dlrs from 889 mln revised from 889 in january and 903 in february 1986 imports dropped to an estimated 879 mln dlrs from 892 revised from 891 in january and 939 in february 1986 the deficit for the eight months to the end of february was 15 mln dlrs as against 057 billion dlrs in the same period year ago

canada february trade surplus billion dlrs canada had trade surplus of 25 billion dlrs in february compared with an upward revised 623 mln dlrs surplus in january statistics canada said the january surplus originally was reported at 533 mln dlrs the february surplus last year was 189 mln dlrs february exports seasonally adjusted were 10 44 billion dlrs against 85 billion in january and 10 05 billion in february 1986 february imports were 19 billion dlrs against 23 billion in january and 86 billion in february 1986

swiss february trade deficit 629 mln francs switzerland had trade deficit of 629 mln swiss francs in february compared with revised 209 mln deficit in january and 723 mln shortfall in february 1986 the federal customs office said february imports were 00 billion francs against exports of 37 billion imports rose in real terms by pct against february 1986 while exports rose by real pct the office said but further improvement in the terms of trade left the deficit smaller than last year last february figure had also been hit by the import of two passenger aircraft
4th qtr balance of payments trade deficit was record 38 37 billion dlrs

favored trade status for moscow still opposed the reagan administration wants to encourage expanded trade with the soviet union but does not believe moscow yet warrants most favored nation treatment deputy secretary of state john whitehead said it seems to me that more trade between us is better than less trade he told forum on soviet trade relations to that end the administration in january allowed foreign policy controls on the export of oil and gas equipment to the soviet union to lapse he said also washington and its allies are reviewing remaining export controls in hopes of simplifying the list of prohibited items and speeding up the licensing process he said whitehead said however the prefential treatment that comes with most favored nation status is out for the moment law prohibits most favored nation status for countries that restrict emigration and other rights what we have seen so far in improved rights under soviet leader mikhail gorbachev are promising trends he said but he added we don know if they will continue we don know how significant they will be
volcker says reducing budget deficit needed to improve trade balance

canada clark sees trade as most urgent problem trade is the most urgent problem facing canadian relations because of pressing need to reach new bilateral pact within the coming months joe clark canadian secretary of state for external affairs said negotiators for the two countries have been meeting for more than year in an effort to work out an agreement the most urgent problem now is the trade question because that has to be decided within the next 10 months clark told the commonwealth club of california we have fast track authority from your congress for approval or rejection of whatever the negotiators achieve clark said that as practical matter an initial agreement must be reached by late september or early october he listed environmental questions particularly acid rain and defense as the second and third most important bilateral issues facing ottawa and washington on wednesday president reagan announced that he will seek billion dlrs from congress to address the acid rain problem some interpreted the move as goodwill gesture in advance of his annual meeting on april in ottawa with prime minister brian mulroney in question and answer session with the public affairs group clark said that the two countries must find better mechanisms for resolving their trade disputes this rash of countervailing actions where we acted on corn and you acted on soft wood and we both said they were quasijudicial the dispute resolution mechanisims in place now are not working adequately in either of our interests he said ottawa also is seeking to change some of washington rules on government procurement that penalize canadian businesses he said there are number of canadian companies that in order to secure substantial contracts in the united states have had to move their head offices out of our country into your country because you have national procurement requirements he said in turn he added the united states would like to change some of the procurement requirements that exist at the provincial government level in canada clark declined to forecast the outcome of the discussions what will come out of it remains for the negotiators in the first instance to propose and then governments and congresses will have judge he said in his prepared remarks clark said that the united states has tended to take canada for granted although it exports to its northern neighbor more than twice what it exports to japan yet you bought almost 10 per cent more from japan last year than you bought from canada he said reuter

south korea moves to slow growth of trade surplus south korea trade surplus is growing too fast and the government has started taking steps to slow it down deputy prime minister kim mahn je said he told press conference the government planned to increase investment speed up the opening of the local market to foreign imports and gradually adjust its currency to hold the surplus at proper level but he said the government would not allow the won to appreciate too much in short period of time south korea has been under pressure from washington to revalue the won the wants south korea to cut its trade surplus with the which rose to billion dlrs in 1986 from billion dlrs in 1985 kim who is also economic planning minister said prospects were bright for the south korean economy but the government would try to hold the current account surplus to around five billion dlrs year for the next five years our government projections of eight pct gnp growth five billion dlrs of current account surplus and 12 pct growth in exports all seemed to be reasonable early this year but now the surplus is growing faster than we expected he said trade ministry officials said south korea exports rose 35 pct to 34 billion dlrs in the first three months of this year while imports rose only pct to billion dlrs kim said the swing of south korea current account to surplus of 65 billion dlrs in 1986 from an 890 mln dlr deficit in 1985 was very significant the surplus enabled the country to reduce its foreign debt last year for the first time south korea foreign debt which fell to 44 billion dlrs in 1986 from 46 billion in 1985 is still among the largest in asia this huge amount of our foreign debt has been one of the major constraints on our development last year was major turning point for the korean economy kim said kim said his government plannned to reduce the ratio of foreign debt to the country gnp to about 20 pct in 1991 from about 50 pct in 1986 the government however does not want to accelerate reducing the debt by making an excessive trade surplus he said kim said sudden rise in the surplus would cause inflation and lead to trade friction with seoul major trading partners particularly the united states we need surplus because we have to reduce our debt but we are taking measures to hold the size of the surplus at proper level kim said

indonesia urged to deregulate its economy world bank president barber conable linked increased borrowing by indonesia the third world sixth largest debtor to fresh measures to deregulate trade and dismantle protectionist barriers we would like to see the indonesian government continue the adjustment process to move towards increased deregulation of the economy conable told press conference at the end of three day visit to jakarta conable directly linked further bank help for indonesia hard pressed balance of payments to further measures by the government to reduce protectionism and increase efficiency the world bank last month granted indonesia 300 mln dlr trade adjustment loan he said further loans would depend on the economic policies indonesia adopted but he said that in meetings with both president suharto and leading indonesian ministers he had not called for specific policy changes the initiative will have to rest with the indonesian government we are not here to dictate to them he stated indonesia the only asian member of opec has been badly hit by last year slump in oil prices which cut its revenues from crude exports in half conable had what he termed frank meeting this morning with suharto he voiced support for measures already taken including september 31 pct devaluation of the rupiah and efforts to deregulate imports and stimulate exports the government can rely on the support of the world bank in continuing program of adjustment to the economic realities of today world he said the bank has loaned indonesia 10 billion dlrs over the past 20 years lending is now about one billion year the world bank would probably like to see further dismantling of tarrif barriers and measures to reduce indonesia protected monopolies in areas like steel plastics and cement western bankers and diplomats said the government has already said it will announce further deregulation measures but has given no timetable it is also considering selling off loss making state companies conable said the bank would try to help indonesia find funds to cover its share of development projects which otherwise would have to be scrapped or postponed japan ex im bank announced 900 mln dlr untied credit last month

turkey current account deficit widens in july turkey current account deficit widened in july to 674 mln dlrs from 454 mln in june but fell from 22 billion in july last year the state statistics institute said the cumulative trade position in july showed 85 billion dlr deficit after 33 billion in june and 89 billion year earlier with exports at 91 billion and imports both fob at 76 billion the government aims to narrow the current account deficit for the whole of 1987 to 975 mln dlrs compared with 52 billion last year up from 01 billion in 1985 bankers forecast the 1987 deficit will exceed one billion dlrs because spurt in exports is expected to slow considerably in the last five months following massive drawdown of inventories

oecd trade growth seen slowing in 1987 the 24 nations of the organisation for economic cooperation and development oecd hampered by sluggish industrial output and trade face slower economic growth and their joint balance of payments will swing into deficit in 1987 the economist intelligence unit eiu said the eiu said in its world trade forecast it revised oecd economic growth downwards to pct this year compared with pct growth forecast in december it said the new areas of weakness are west germany and the smaller european countries it influences and japan hardest hit by currency appreciation this year the independent research organisation cut its 1987 growth rate forecasts for west germany to pct from pct in december and to pct from three pct for japan it said it expected the oecd to post current account deficit of some 13 billion dlrs in both 1987 and 1988 due in large part to 50 dlrs barrel rise in 1987 oil prices it said the current account deficit looked likely to fall even more slowly than forecast to 125 billion dlrs in 1987 and 115 billion in 1988 from 130 billion in 1986 it said it expected west germany to post 31 billion dlr payments surplus and japan 76 billion dlr surplus this year the eiu said it saw oil prices dropping to around 16 50 dlrs barrel by end 1987 and 15 50 dlrs in 1988 from about 18 dlrs last year as adherence to opec output policy becomes increasingly ragged it said the dollar is poised to resume its decline in foreign exchange markets and will lose further 13 pct on its trade weighted index this year and five pct in 1988 after last year 18 pct drop the average mark dollar rate is put at 80 marks this year and 70 in 1988 while the yen dollar rate is expected to break through the 150 yen barrier with an average value of 150 yen in 1987 and 146 yen in 1988 it said this is not crash scenario but the dollar steeper angle of descent increases the risk of ending with fireball rather than three point landing the eiu said talking will not stop the dollar slide for long and the february meeting of finance ministers of the group of five and canada produced scant promise of either decisive shift to more expansive policies in west germany and japan or tighter fsical policy it said it said the key to the dollar fortunes was the willingness of japanese institutions to buy government assets despite prospects of sustaining currency loss thus far they have been willing the eic said adding that if japan was deterred from buying bonds the dollar would collapse to contain such currency crisis dollar interest rates would have to soar bringing recession and third world debt crisis it said on trade the eiu said prospects for 1987 look increasingly sick import growth forecast in december at pct is now seen slowing down to around pct in 1987 with recovery only to pct in 1988 it said the weakness of the west german economy is the biggest single factor with import growth there expected to feature sluggish pct growth in 1987 against the pct forecast in december the eiu said on the export side it said it saw weak demand in west germany affecting export prospects elsewhere in europe while japan exports in 1987 would remain flat and sales by exporters would respond only marginally to lower more competitively priced dollar it said in most of europe and in japan raw materials and oil will cost less in domestic currency in 1987 than in 1986

payments gap to persist ex fed chief says the dollar will decline over the next two to three years but this is unlikely to result in complete reduction of the current account deficit said anthony solomon chairman of warburg usa inc and former president of the federal reserve bank of new york in presentation to the japan society solomon said without elaboration that he expects significant decline in the dollar within the next three years the dollar will fall more but the current account deficit will stop being reduced when it reaches its structural core he said solomon described the structural core as about one half of the current 150 billion dlr annual deficit he cited several factors which will prevent an elimination of the deficit for one thing it is unlikely that there will be any new investment in those manufacturing industries that shrank when the dollar was at uncompetitive levels he said in addition he said that the has an increased propensity to import in order to satisify consumer tastes solomon forecast inflation at pct by year end but said it could be kept below five pct in the medium term if oil prices are stable and commodity values remain low

toshiba sharp restrain lap top pc exports to ec toshiba corp lt tsba and sharp corp lt shrp decided to maintain exports of lap top personal computers to the european community ec at last year levels despite the halt of shipments to the company spokesmen told reuters they said the voluntary restraints were aimed at averting ec sanctions urged by european computer makers the europeans feared japanese personal computers would flood ec markets after washington imposed 100 pct tariffs last april toshiba and sharp together control about 40 pct of the personal computer market in the ec the sharp spokesman said toshiba said exports of t1100 and t3100 lap top computers would continue at 000 units month for the time being sharp said exports to the ec of pc 7000 series lap top personal computers would continue at last year level of 12 000 to 16 000 units year washington imposed the tariffs because of japan alleged failure to uphold 1986 agreement on semiconductor trade

japan says oecd study on subsidies still ongoing japanese agriculture ministry officials said study of agriculture subsidies by the organisation for economic cooperation and development oecd is still under way and will be completed sometime next month the officials said the study has been inaccurate so far and they said japan would comment on the final results reuter report from washington yesterday said the study has found that japan has the highest agriculture subsidies in the world and that dairy farmers benefit more than any other commodity producers from subsidies the study has not been officially released due to objections from some countries japan has withdrawn its objection and decided to accept the release of the study the agriculture ministry officials said oecd directors are expected to approve the release at meeting in mid may one agriculture ministry source said the study so far was based on the years 1979 81 japanese subsidies have dropped sharply since then partly because of tight budgetary policy and foreign currency factors have also changed he said the study is unfair and unacceptable because it does not take account of various differences in farming conditions in each country such as geography the source said he said it is highly likely that the final study will show japan has the highest farm subsidies in the world this would increase foreign pressure to open japan farm market further but this would have little impact on japan agriculture policy he said without giving further details main purpose of the study is to clarify export subsidies by major exporting nations like the united states and the european community but japan is major importer he said

treasury baker opposes tax increase treasury secretary james baker said that he opposes federal tax increase to help reduce the budget deficit and favors spending cuts instead don think it tax increase is very good idea and quite confident that president reagan doesn think it very good idea baker said in an interview on cable news network moneyline television program he said taxpayers are taxed at rate of 19 pct of gnp which is traditionally where it has been but the federal government is spending at rate of 24 pct of gnp baker said spending cuts are clearly the best way to cut budget deficits baker said he opposed stock transactions tax proposed by house speaker jim wright tex or other special taxes the stock transfer tax would be particularly unfortunate approach to take the treasury secretary said he said the united states has some of the most efficient capital markets in the world and new taxes would impair efficiency on the international front baker said banks must do more lending to developing countries he was questioned about this after the standard and poor corp downgrading today of the debt of six major money center bank holding companies largely because of their heavy developing nation loan exposure baker said that developing countries must adopt free market economic policies such as in the united states he said capital flows will be required to support the needed reforms in the economic systems of those countries the money must come either through equity or debt and baker said that developing nations investment regimes do not support enough equity investment so you ve got to have some debt there commenting on the trade deficit baker said think you re going to see 15 to 20 billion dlr reduction this year

soviet economist sees few gains in trade there is little chance soviet exports to the united states will rise in 1987 but moscow current trade reforms should result in more trade in manufactured goods in future soviet economist said sergey frolov chief economist at amtorg trading corp an agent for soviet trade organisations and industries told ussr business meeting the soviet union produces few items that western nations want but reforms including upgrading the quality of goods and allowing joint ventures with foreign firms will encourage modest export gains in future frolov said the soviet union exported 500 mln dlrs worth of goods to the united states in 1986 and imported billion dlrs worth he gave no trade forecast for 1987 but he said that even if all obstacles were removed total trade between the two countries would remain between two and three billion dlrs year the post detente embargoes have taught the ussr to limit its trading with the he said

envoy advises nakasone to prepare for visit the japanese ambassador to the suggested that prime minister yasuhiro nakasone make efforts to present advanced proposals on trade issues when he visits washington next month ambassador nobuo matsunaga made the recommendation at meeting with nakasone kyodo news service said matsunaga also advised that the prime minister should be prepared to discuss japan economic issues matsunaga cited issues such as japan micro chip trade pact foreign access to the kansai international airport project and new international telecommunications firm matsunaga returned on sunday to report to japanese leaders on recent developments over trade in preparation for nakasone visit to washington april 29 to may kyodo quoted nakasone as telling reporters after meeting the envoy entirely accept what ambassador matsunaga recommended nakasone did not elaborate the japan trade dispute intensified last week when president ronald reagan said the would impose heavy tariffs on japanese imports in retaliation against alleged japanese breach of the computer chip trade pact meanwhile nakasone ruling liberal democratic party ldp is to consider measures to boost imports and open up the japanese market such as government purchase of supercomputers and expanding foreign access to the kansai airport project party sources said the ldp international economic affairs council was responding to nakasone request for measures to reduce japan increasing trade surpluses with the and europe they said

french 1986 current account surplus revised the french 1986 current account balance of payments surplus has been revised slightly upwards to 25 billion francs from the 25 billion franc figure announced last month the finance ministry said this compares with billion deficit in 1985 and while it is the first surplus since 1979 is substantially lower than the 50 billion surplus forecast by the previous socialist government before they lost office in march last year net long term capital outflows rose sharply to 70 billion francs last year from billion in 1985 largely due to major program of foreign debt repayment the ministry said in the fourth quarter alone the unadjusted surplus rose to 14 billion francs from billion the previous quarter but the adjusted surplus fell to billion from billion fourth quarter medium and long term foreign debt repayments exceeded new credits by 11 billion francs

brazil trade surplus doubled in february brazil trade surplus doubled in february to 261 mln dlrs from january 129 mln but was well below the 628 mln dlrs of february last year official figures show director of the banco do brasil foreign trade department cacex roberto fendt told reporters the upturn in february confirmed rising trend in exports which totalled 53 billion dlrs against 26 billion in january and after excluding coffee and oil derivatives was only slightly below the same month last year coffee earnings were down to 110 mln dlrs against 295 mln in february 1986 because of lower prices he added fendt said although the february results were lower than the average expected for the rest of the year the government target of an eight billion dlr surplus for 1987 should be achieved this would compare with 1986 surplus of billion dlrs exports this year are expected to total 22 billion dlrs and imports 14 billion he added in 1986 exports totalled 22 billion dlrs and imports 12 billion fendt said the rise in imports in february to 27 billion dlrs from 12 billion in february last year was in line with government plans to foster economic growth fendt said imports were running at levels well above the traditional average for brazil imports in the first two months of the year excluding oil and wheat totalled billion dlrs against 47 billion in the same 1986 period this rise reflected industry need for equipment to raise production and is perfectly compatible with the government program for economic growth fendt added

ec official faults trade bill sir roy denman head of the ec delegation in washington said pending trade legislation is misguided attempt to deal with the nation trade deficit and will spark retaliation if passed in its present form to think that you can deal with trade deficit by legislation is mistake he told the foreign trade association here denman told reporters that possible retaliation which he warned of in letter to house ways and means committee chairman dan rostenkowski would not necessarily be on product for product basis retaliation does not have to be matched product to product denman said he said in the case of textiles import restrictions however retaliation would be against textile exports certainly if restrictions were imposed on european exports of textiles to the the community would be likely to retaliate with restrictions on textile exports to europe denman said he also took exception to proposals to require countries with large current account surpluses with the to cut those surpluses or face special tariffs this would conflict with international obligations throw large wrench into the current round of trade negotiations and could easily boomerang he warned of the tariff proposals denman also took exception to efforts to seek reciprocity in specific trade sectors forcing reciprocity in one sector by imposing barriers would simply lead to retaliation from the other party he said adding that overall reciprocity can only be achieved by trading off disadvantages in one sector for advantages in another

shultz warns asean of looming trade problem secretary of state george shultz warned members of the association of southeast asian nations asean they could no longer rely on increased exports to the for growth given the importance of exports particularly export manufactures to all of your countries you are going to have to work hard to diversify your markets he said while you may be able to maintain your current market share in the you clearly will not be able to look to the to take major increases in your exports he added shultz told the foreign ministers of brunei indonesia malaysia the philippines singapore and thailand the would cut its huge foreign trade deficit more rapidly than many now believed he said asean looming trade problems would not necessarily stem from protectionist legislation now being contemplated by congress but simply because of the adjustments the economy will have to make in order to service our large and growing external debt shultz said the deficit had resulted not from falling exports but from higher imports that had fuelled world growth

australia attacks gatt farm rules exemption australia accused the of increasing protectionism on agricultural products and called for an end to washington special 32 year exemption from certain gatt rules on agricultural trade robert arnott australia delegate to the general agreement on tariffs and trade gatt made the appeal at special annual meeting which reviews the 1955 waiver australia today said the united states goals of reducing barriers to agricultural trade were being contradicted by actions which in fact increased protection in trade in agriculture the australian delegation said in statement the united states section 22 waiver is one of the basic flaws in the gatt coverage of agriculture arnott told the meeting arnott said the waiver had continually been used as justification for dubious protective measures by the he listed recent dairy export incentive program and steps to close the sugar market to imports he also told reuters the waiver allowed washington to impose quotas on imports of farm products where it had domestic support programs this covered imports of dairy products peanuts cotton and sugar asked to comment michael samuels ambassador to the gatt told reuters these charges have been made since the very beginning the waiver is part of domestic agricultural policy part of our law when we joined the gatt we have agreed to put the waiver on the table during the uruguay round and invite other countries to do the same with their programs we can negotiate them all samuels added ninety two nations are taking part in the four year uruguay round of talks launched in punta del este last september bargaining in agricultural goods and services banking tourism insurance is included for the first time as well as manufactured goods

trade issues straining ec patience with japan member states of the european community are starting to run out of patience with japan which they believe has repeatedly promised major initiatives to open its market to imports but as often made only minor moves diplomatic sources here said several recent actions by ec countries bear witness to new disillusionment with the willingness or at least the ability of the japanese government to reduce its massive trade surplus with the ec however they said an all out trade war may be far off as ec states know they would suffer almost as much as japan senior ec diplomats gave generally favourable reaction to an ec executive commission proposal under which the ec could raise tariffs on range of japanese products if the carries out threat to make similar move on april 17 the ec tariffs which would involve renouncing obligations entered into with the world trade body gatt would be designed to stop diversion of exports to the ec market from that of the the diplomats were meeting as tokyo announced that the ec trade deficit with japan reached record 13 billion dlrs in march up from 94 billion in february in 1986 japanese exports to the ec totalled 30 67 billion dlrs up pct from 1985 while ec exports to japan fell one pct to 12 43 billion dlrs in paris trade minister michel noir said france has decided to give japan taste of its own medicine burgeoning imports of microwave ovens and of frozen coquilles st jacques will be restricted by strict application of french quality standards something ec states say often happens to their own exports entering japan britain has threatened to withdraw the licences of japanese banks and insurance companies to operate in the city of london because the british cable and wireless company lost out in competition for japanese telecommucations contract however british officials in london have said that the government may have gone too far in implying that it would take immediate drastic action unless the contract was reopened by contrast west germany with the ec most successful economy has never threatened tokyo with sanctions preferring to rely on firm diplomacy and encouragement of its own industries to surmount obstacles to export to japan the ec commission itself has switched its tactics in recent years substituting general calls for action by japan to open its market with specific demands for moves in key areas at present it is for instance pressuring japan to end allegedly discriminatory taxation of imported wines and spirits to ensure ec companies have chance to win contracts for the building of new international airport and to simplify certification and safety checks on imported cars ec officials say these tactics yield some benefits but often the japanese announce modifications of their non tariff barriers which open the door to imports by only token amount they stress however that any action must be taken by the ec as whole to stop beggar my neighbour action one of the problems britain could face if it were to withdraw licences for japanese banks would be that the bankers would be welcomed with open arms in frankfurt or amsterdam they point out
