trade surplus cut would benefit japan sumita bank of japan governor satoshi sumita said it is in japan national interest to make greater efforts to reduce its trade surplus he told business executives the most important issues for the world economy are the correction of international trade imbalances and solution to the world debt problem to this end japan and the must make medium and long term efforts to alter economic structures which have expanded the trade gap between the two nations world economic growth and therefore an expansion of debtor countries export markets are needed to solve the debt issue he added

yeutter says japan trade difficulties remain trade representative clayton yeutter said he was unsure whether some of the trade issues straining japanese relations would be resolved before the two countries open trade talks in late april we are having high level discussions on them the issues within the united states the relationship on some of those is very strained between us japan at the moment and we need to relieve those strains at the earliest possible date he said am not sure we can wait until late april he added yeutter is in new zealand for two day informal meeting of trade ministers who are reviewing the uruguay round of the general agreement on trade and tariffs gatt he said he will meet the japanese delegation over the next few days but declined to discuss methods of relieving the strain between the two countries yeutter said earlier the three most contentious trade issues were semiconductors japanese government unwillingness to allow public entities to buy super computers and the barring of firms from the eight billion dlr kansai airport project near osaka the japanese delegation to the gatt talks said in statement yesterday they are making major efforts to dismantle trade barriers in their country am convinced that they are attempting to move their policies in the right direction the question is how far and how fast yeutter said

japan set to begin high level trade talks japan and the kick off top level trade talks tomorrow amid signs officials from both sides are growing increasingly irritated with each other the talks held annually at sub cabinet level to review the whole gamut of japan economic relations will pave the way for american secretary of state george schultz one day stop over here at end week on his way home from china faced with growing congressional protectionist pressure the administration is pressing japan for speedy action to reduce its still huge trade surplus officials said we appreciate their frustration senior japanese government official said but we are also frustrated the official said the 40 pct rise of the yen over the last 18 months has hit japan hard forcing exporters to slash spending and lay off workers to make up for lost sales abroad that has not yet shown up in dollar based statistics on trade but it will he said he said the administration was ignoring the progress that has been made and instead emphasizing the problems that remain when it talks with congress it would only take five minutes to list their accomplishments senior official replied the talks begin tomorrow with high level discussions on the economic structures of both countries and how they affect the bilateral trade imbalance which last year amounted to 51 48 billion dlrs in japan favour on the following two days the topics will range from multilateral trade talks under the auspices of the general agreement on tariffs and trade gatt to such bilateral trade problems as super computers the structural talks are intended to be free wheeling discussions among senior officials tomorrow topics include savings and investment issues such as consumer credit and housing and the implications of government budget deficits these talks come at particularly delicate time for the japanese government which is facing increasing domestic pressure to abandon its tight fisted fiscal policy and stimulate the sagging economy by spending more some officials complained japan has no intention of boosting domestic demand and imports as washington wants japanese officials in turn pointed the finger at the huge budget deficit as one of the main culprits for the trade imbalance that budget deficit has meant that the is buying more imports japan seems particularly peeved at being singled in draft trade bill before the senate as nation following adverserial trade practices it condemns japan without due process one japanese official said that reference spoils what is otherwise well thought out bill introduced by democratic senator lloyd bentsen he said japan is also not totally happy with the administration trade bill particularly its proposal to establish reciprocal access to foreign markets as one criteria for retaliatory trade action by the officials said nevertheless japanese officials said they remain in weak bargaining position especially with the threat of trade bill overhanging them we have no leverage one official admitted as result tokyo is striving to meet complaints about its trade practices in variety of fields including super computers the is pressing for greater access to the japanese super computer market the japanese government has sent long questionnaire to public institutions like universities which buy the sophisticated machines in hopes of eventually setting up informal bidding procedures easily understood by all potential sellers officials said

taiwan to boost farm imports from europe taiwan is expected to boost agricultural imports from the and europe in calendar 1987 to help balance trade the council of agriculture said council official who declined to be named told reuters the imports which will include about seven mln tonnes of oilseeds grains and dairy products would be worth some four billion dlrs against 72 billion in 1986 and 38 billion in 1985 taiwan surplus with the rose to 13 billion dlrs last year from 10 billion in 1985 government figures show government figures also show taiwan surplus with europe rose to 53 billion dlrs last year from 543 mln in 1985 taiwan imports of farm produce last year amounted to 41 billion dlrs against 52 billion in 1985 imports from europe rose to 182 mln dlrs from 148 mln the official said he attributed the decline in the value of imports to falling agricultural products prices last year

economic spotlight deficit with nics the trade deficit with taiwan and korea is expected to widen this year despite some economic and currency adjustments by the two newly industrialized countries economists said the surpluses that taiwan and korea ran with the in 1986 will get bigger this time next year the will be screaming at those countries about their exports said steve cerier of manufacturers hanover trust co taiwan is currently the third biggest exporter to the after japan and canada while korea is the seventh largest faced with heightened protectionist sentiment in congress the reagan administration has been stepping up the rhetoric against taiwan and korea urging those countries to allow their currencies to appreciate and lift impediments to free trade the thrust has shifted to those newly industrialized countries nics amid signs the dollar steep drop against the currencies of japan and most ec nations previously the main focus of the drive to cut its trade gap is beginning to close the competiveness gap for american goods treasury secretary james baker said recently that he expects reduction in japan trade surplus this year but manufacturers still are losing markets on their own doorstep to taiwan and korea whose currencies have not risen as much as the yen and the mark as major beneficiaries of soft oil prices and with low labor costs taiwanese and korean exporters are well placed to take up the slack in 1986 the fashionable comment in washington was japan bashing now it nic bashing said robert chandross of lloyds bank plc asia four main nics hong kong south korea singapore and taiwan accounted for almost one fifth of the overall 170 billion dlr merchandise trade deficit for 1986 the trade gap with taiwan rose to 15 billion dlrs in 1986 from 13 billion in 1985 while the bilateral trade deficit with south korea grew to billion from billion and preliminary data show that the growth trend is continuing the trade shortfall with taiwan was billion dlrs in january up 24 pct from year earlier the gap with korea was 700 mln dlrs up 24 pct from year ago lately both nations have said they will take steps to defuse incipient trade tensions korea said it is choosing many of the 122 items on which the wants it to cut import tariffs in order to deflect pressure for currency revaluation still south korean trade minister rha woong bae said last week that korea would maintain trade surplus for three to five years as way to cut its 44 billion dlr foreign debt for its part taiwan said in january that it will cut tariffs on 700 goods sometime in the second half of 1987 and try to diversify exports but vice economic minister wang chien shien said last month that he still does not expect taiwan trade surplus with the will fall in 1987 the nics have made deep inroads into markets for textiles and electronic goods but korea is raising its profile in the area of big ticket manufactured goods notably cars korea expects its auto exports mostly for north america to balloon to 675 000 units in 1987 from zero in 1985 the nics exports are almost all manufactured goods when their exports rise it hits the heart of the manufacturing base it cuts directly to us and to our customers said bob wendt manager for economic studies at bethlehem steel corp the takes 90 pct of korea computer products exports 72 pct of its electrical appliances and 65 pct of its telecommunications equipment recent study by morgan guaranty trust co says taiwan and south korea are the most pressing trade issue for the while hong kong and singapore run trade surpluses with the these are offset by their deficits with other countries but taiwan and to lesser extent south korea stand in marked contrast both of these nations have moved rapidly into large bilateral surplus with the and major overrall trade and current account surpluses the morgan study says morgan expects taiwan overall trade surplus to grow to 18 billion dlrs in 1987 from 15 billion last year and korea to increase to billion dlrs from billion concern about the nics is not confined to the lot of korea and taiwan exports to the have been at japan expense said richard koss at general motors corp february paris meeting of six major industrial powers exorted nics to lower trade barriers and revalue currencies but this two pronged approach has drawn little response from the two nations so far and in any case will only work with sizeable lag economists say the has not said how much it thinks the taiwan and korea currencies should climb the taiwan dollar which is pegged to the dollar has risen about 15 pct since september 1985 while the korean won has risen about five pct but in real terms the taiwan dollar has been flat against the unit and the won has lost seven pct economists say we ve not seen any lessening of competition from those countries that we can attribute to currency changes said bethlehem steel wendt and so far pleas for taiwan and korea to use their hefty export earnings to import more have had little effect moreover it is uncertain how far protectionism will get given the administration free trade stance it hard to see that anything will be passed much before year end and then the question is will it have teeth one economist said

chipmakers urge sanctions against japan the semiconductor industry association urged the government to impose trade sanctions against japan for violating the japan semiconductor trade agreement in letter to treasury secretary james baker the group said sanctions should be imposed against japanese chipmakers as of april and continue until the is satisfied there is full compliance with the agreement the group said action by japan to cut back on semiconductor exports is not what is required america interests require that agreements be honored and that industries not bear the burden for the persistent unwillingness or inability of the government of japan to deliver on its commitments the trade group said the white house economic policy council is expected to discuss possible sanctions against japan at meeting scheduled for thursday the trade group said japan has not lived up to the terms of the agreement last year which was aimed at ending japanese dumping of semiconductors and at opening japanese markets to foreign based manufacturers

hungarian economy continues unfavourable trend hungary economy and hard currency trade have failed so far this year to reverse two year unfavourable trend the official hungarian news agency mti said industrial production in january and february was only pct up on the same 1986 period mti said while hard currency exports fell six pct as imports rose 10 pct hungary hard currency trade fell into deficit of 539 mln dlrs last year from surplus of 295 mln in 1985 and billion in 1984 mti quoted government spokesman saying last december wage freeze decree would expire on april as envisaged gross domestic product grew sluggish one pct in 1986 after stagnating in 1985 and growing pct in 1984

usx lt chairman calls for lower dollar usx corp chairman david roderick called for lower value for the dollar against other currencies to help speed correction in the trade deficit which last year reached 170 billion dlrs in remarks prepared for speech before the economic club of detroit roderick said there should be total resolve that the dollar versus other major currencies as well as the currencies of other nations having substantial trade surplus with us must continue to decline so that the correction in our trade deficit starts on the road to recovery roderick said the should be understanding of the economic pain our trading partners experience as result of falling dollar but he added as painful as the correction may be to our trading partners it is less painful than leaving the problem uncorrected because that would lead us into an inevitable lengthy and steep world recession roderick said between february 1985 and december 1986 the dollar fell by more than 40 pct in real terms against major industrial currencies and by 30 to 35 pct against broader group of currencies of nearly all developing nations at the end of 1986 he said the value of foreign assets in the exceeded the value of assets abroad by 240 billion dlrs compared to five years ago when the had surplus in assets of 141 billion company spokesman said the data were provided by economic consultants to usx the primary reason for the trade imbalance was the 70 pct rise of the dollar between 1980 and 1985 although other factors were involved roderick said but it is wrong he said to attribute the massive trade deficit to fundmental deterioration of productivity or of american product quality these areas need to be improved but they are not the root cause of the trade gap problem roderick said he urged american manufacturers to become more competitive so they can compete in global markets in the speech the usx chairman also called for changes in securities laws to curb what he called abuses by corporate raiders and speculators among his proposals which he presented to the senate banking committee in testimony last week were requirement that raiders give 24 hour notice for every one pct of stock they acquire in company roderick proposed that tender offers must be made for all cash to all stockholders on equal terms and that raiders be required to have financing in place before tender is made further raiders should be required to make an all cash tender offer once they acquire 10 pct of target company stock he said and payment of greenmail or preferential price by target company to buy back raider stake should be prohibited under the revised laws roderick said changes were necessary to curb abuses but that he did not want laws that would hurt the financial markets or discourage fair price to all takeovers

soviet union seen watching china gatt application china application to join the general agreement on tariffs and trade gatt is seen as test case by the soviet union which will probably demand to follow china top european community official said willy de clercq external relations commissioner of the european communities told news conference that china application would involve long and difficult negotiations china formally applied to join gatt in july 1986 and in february presented memorandum backing its application which de clercq said was now being studied questions would then be presented to china after china other important state trading countries including the soviet union will probably demand accession china application could be considered test case he said he said the ec strongly backed china application but others among gatt 92 contracting parties took tougher line among the numerous problems of huge centrally run economy entering free trade system are tariffs and reciprocity and the expectation that china will practice an open trade policy without trade discrimination de clercq added de clercq noted the different dimensions of the chinese economy and those of hungary and yugoslavia the two current socialist gatt members on china import potential he said foreign exchange shortage would force china to import less this year and next than in the past with an emphasis on technological equipment and capital during his visit de clercq has met top chinese leaders and today signed an agreement to open european community commission office in peking
